title: Bring Your Own Device
author: NCSC
summary:
This tabletop exercise explores the risks of a Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) policy and the controls in place to mitigate them. The scenario covers incidents such as data leaks and malware infections on employees' personal devices used for work. It facilitates discussion on policies, training, securing corporate data on personal devices, incident management, legal/regulatory issues, and procedures for employee departure or lost/stolen devices.

The exercise aims to evaluate and practise response skills, identify gaps in plans, and build relationships between key stakeholders.

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Home and Remote Working
author: NCSC
summary:
This scenario explores the events that take place where employees in your organisation need to work remotely at short notice and require access to the IT services used by your organisation.

It includes connecting employees to systems via non-corporate internet connections, processes and monitoring for secure distributed communication using various online systems, and procedures for handling information compromise when working remotely. Discussion of these topics will help explore the controls your organisation has in place to facilitate effective distributed working and to identify and respond to information compromise from your organisation.

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Supply Chain Software
author: NCSC
summary:
This scenario explores an incident in which critical third-party software that is critical in your organisation is determined to have been compromised. This compromise can enable remote access by unauthorised users, potentially leading to a serious cyber incident, such as ransomware being deployed effectively via the supply chain.

The scenario begins with the organisation requiring and selecting a new IT management software package from external suppliers, which is subsequently deployed into the network. It then progresses through reports of a major IT software provider cyber attack, confirmation from the supplier that your organisation is using an impacted version of the software, and the understanding that attackers replaced the latest version with a malicious version.

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Third Party Software Compromise
author: NCSC
summary:
This scenario investigates the risks around using third party software and the controls your organisation has in place to mitigate the impact of a third party supplier being compromised. In particular, the exercise looks at password controls, the ability to detect and respond to a compromise and the ability to cope with disruption to key services.

The objective of this exercise is to explore how your organisation would respond to the compromise of a third party supplier. Discussions will cover the detection and response capability of your organisation, processes for dealing with service disruption, and policies in place to prevent stolen credentials being used to compromise network services. The outcomes of discussions around the events in this scenario can be an opportunity to identify areas for improvement.

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Managing A Vulnerability Disclosure
author: NCSC
summary:
This scenario covers the events following the disclosure of a vulnerability in a public facing web application run by your organisation. It includes managing communication between your organisation and a person reporting a vulnerability, specifically starting with a report received via social media.

The exercise then progresses through the exploitation of the vulnerability, resulting in the takeover of a subdomain and the hosting of malicious content to leverage user trust. This leads to significant user concern and media enquiries.

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Threatened Leak of Sensitive Data
author: NCSC
summary:
This scenario covers the events following an anonymous email being received by an employee threatening to release sensitive information about your organisation’s employees.

It includes the following.

  1. Your organisation’s logging and monitoring of internal sensitive documents
  2. Your processes for securely offboarding a disgruntled employee and escalating a security incident internally
  3. Legal activities following such an incident

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Supply Chain Ransomware
author: NCSC
summary:
This scenario explores an incident in which a major supplier integrated with your operations is subject to a ransomware attack, with the ransomware subsequently spreading to your organisation.

The commercialisation of Ransomware as a Service (RaaS) by criminals has been a significant factor in the growth of ransomware attacks. You should be prepared to respond to a ransomware attack to ensure that you can limit the impact to operations.

You are encouraged to discuss how you will respond, initially to the supplier incident and then to your incident, and your response to subsequent demands for payment from criminals. You can also discuss your approach to cyber insurance, and your communications in response to a leak of sensitive data.

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Heightened Cyber Threat
author: NCSC
summary:
The 'Heightened cyber threat' exercise is a tabletop exercise designed to help organisations evaluate and practice their skills and decision-making mechanisms for responding to cyber incidents, specifically during periods of increased threat. It is described as an immersive and effective way to test an organisation's ability to respond. Running this exercise is presented as one of the most cost-effective ways to test cyber incident response capabilities.

The scenario explores an incident that leads to an increased threat of cyber attack, which could result from situations like a new zero-day exploit being actively used, negative press surrounding the organisation, or geo-political tensions between nation states. Participants are encouraged to discuss how such a situation would impact their organisation, including managing systems, detecting threats, responding to the increased threat level, cyber insurance, and long-term resilience planning.

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Ransomware Attack By Phishing Email
author: NCSC
summary:
This scenario details a ransomware attack initiated by a phishing email, to evaluate the organisation's preparedness and existing security measures.

The exercise progresses from the initial malicious email and subsequent malware infection to the impact of ransomware encrypting data and the public relations fallout, ultimately aiming to help organisations identify areas for improvement in their cybersecurity defenses and incident response plans.

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Mobile Phone Theft and Response
author: NCSC
summary:
This tabletop exercise simulates a scenario where a user misplaces an organisation-provisioned mobile phone, which is subsequently stolen.

The exercise explores your organisation's readiness to handle incidents involving lost or stolen mobile devices, focusing on mobile device security measures, incident response procedures, and communication strategies.

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Attack from Unknown Wifi
author: NCSC
summary:
This scenario covers the entire sequence of events that could occur when a user connects to an unknown wifi network.

It discusses the risks taken when connected to such a wifi network and how an attacker may use that to access a user’s device, such as a laptop.

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Supply Chain
author: NCSC
summary:
This scenario covers the entire sequence of events that could occur when a user connects to an unknown wifi network.

It discusses the risks taken when connected to such a wifi network and how an attacker may use that to access a user’s device, such as a laptop.

The use of outdated software, which commonly contain security issues, is also covered as a method of the attacker compromising the user’s device.

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Insider Threat Resulting in a Data Breach
author: NCSC
summary:
An exercise covering the events following the discovery that a user has **shared sensitive documents with an unauthorised third party**.

It discusses the processes your organisation has in place to **verify the source of leaked information** and determine if its exposure was malicious or due to user error. The use of **USB and removable media** within the organisation and associated security policies is also discussed.

Finally, the scenario asks you to consider the **regulatory impact of a data breach**, in this scenario following a compromise by an insider, and how your organisation would respond.

Discussing these events will help you explore the **risks and impact of an Insider Threat** resulting in a data breach. You will be able to discuss the procedures you have in place to **trace the source of leaked information** and how removable media and file sharing services are used and managed within your organisation. You should also discuss how your organisation would **respond to a data breach**, which may include the relevant authorities to contact, your communications approach following a breach to staff and customers and how this risk can be reduced in the future.

(Exercise content translated from NCSC's 'Exercise-in-a-Box' materials - www.ncsc.gov.uk)

title: Exercise 'Cold Start'
author: SC3
summary:
This exercise is designed to explore the impact of a cyber attack that results in the loss of a critical IT function that supports the Business Area. This loss could either be as a direct result of the cyber incident or a containment put in place removing the service to enable forensic investigation.

The scenario is fictitious although plausible. It is designed to encourage thoughtful responses and values everyone’s views during the exercise.

For each inject, a Quiz response question is posed to get the conversation started. This is followed by some specific discussion questions to broaden the discussion.
